text:
Unique Particle Attribution constraints in:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-1/#non-ambig

specify that 2 <element> declarations with the same namespace and name may not 
appear inside a <choice>.  Here is an example which violates this constraint 
and no error is reported by the parser.

NOTE! If the test is changed so that the offending <complexType> is referenced 
in the instance document, a proper error is produced ... so the severity here 
is Minor.

3_8si08.xsd
===========
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<schema xmlns          ="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:si       ="http://www.schemaTest.org/3_8si"
        targetNamespace="http://www.schemaTest.org/3_8si">

<complexType name="badType">
  <choice>
    <element name="elem1" type="string" form="qualified"/>
    <element ref="si:elem1"/>
  </choice>
</complexType>

<element name="elem1" type="string"/>

<element name="root" type="string"/>

</schema>

3_8si08.xml
===========
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<si:root xmlns:xsi         ="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xmlns:si          ="http://www.schemaTest.org/3_8si"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.schemaTest.org/3_8si
                             3_8si08.xsd">
</si:root>
creator: mhuffman@ca.ibm.com
sandygao@ca.ibm.com
text:
The UPA checking was done at validating time, so UPA errors won't be reported 
if a content model is not referenced from the instance document.
Now the checking is done after we traverse the schema, so UPA errors are 
reported no matter whether it's referenced or not.
